newsitem.title: CHINA: China's infrastructure eyes foreign investment.
newsitem.headline: China's infrastructure eyes foreign investment.

text.p: China's infrastructure sector will open its domestic market to foreign investment further in the next 15 years, the China News Service said on Thursday.

China plans to raise at least $30 billion from abroad for road construction in the next five years, it said, quoting a report by Wang Luolin and Jiang Xiaojuan of the think-tank, the China Academy of Social Sciences (CASS).
The telecommunications sector needed $6.0 billion in foreign investment in the same period, the report said.
The State Planning Commission was also seeking investment for some key projects, including the Three Gorges Dam project and construction of highways between Beijing and Shanghai, it said.
Direct foreign investment in China is expected to rise an average 10.2 percent a year from 1996 to 2000, to total $230-270 billion in the five-year period, state media said.

State statisticians had calculated that if annual economic growth was around 8.0 percent, China would need $50 billion in direct foreign investment each year. If annual growth rose to 9.0 percent, $90 billion would be required.
